topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54f3ead76368724087b70400#post_54f3ead76368724087b70400
The number one thing I've learned from helping take care of autistic children is: DO NOT GET UPSET OR ANGRY!

What I mean by this is that I've helped babysit severely autistic children; if you're getting upset then that's just going to get them more upset that you're upset at them.

What I used to do if he was having a episode would be to pick him up and calmly and rationally ask him what's wrong and if he wasn't listening calmly say to him "if you don't tell me what's wrong then I can't help okay?" and so forth while basically babying him by patting him on the back and such.

The worst case I ever saw was it took him six hours to finally fucking calm down.  That six hours episode illustrated what you don't ever do with autistic children in that don't ever get angry or upset at them cause if you get upset that will get them upset.  Every time it was time for me and his mom to switch out watching him she would get upset and after a few minutes tell him to be quiet to which then I would have to pick him up and tell him it was okay and that everyone was just crabby and tired.  Eventually she just called it quits for the night and left him to me and it took two hours after she left for me to calm him down cause he was extremely upset that she was upset at him.

Moral of the story: don't yell at autistic children.

Raising kids is okay; just takes a ton of patience.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54f3ec9e6368725b26d00c00#post_54f3ec9e6368725b26d00c00
You should never get angry with children in general. Kids take things more personally than adults. And when a child does screw up, and they WILL, you condemn the action not the individual. And never EVER speak down to a child. They haaaaaaate it.
